qas.question: Who was dean of Yale Medical School from 1920 to 1935?
What was the driving force behind Milton Winternitz's research?
What teaching style did Milton Winternitz develop?

answers.text: few lectures and fewer exams, and strengthened the full-time faculty system

qas.question: What programs did Milton Winternitz create?

answers.text: graduate-level Yale School of Nursing and the Psychiatry Department

qas.question: Who was dean of Yale Medical School from 1925 to 1935?
What wasn't the driving force behind Milton Winternitz's research?
What teaching style did Milton Winternitz reject?

plausible_answers.text: few lectures and fewer exams, and strengthened the full-time faculty system
graduate-level Yale School of Nursing and the Psychiatry Department

qas.question: What programs did Milton Winternitz end?

context: <a0_0><b5_0>Milton Winternitz<b5_0/><a0_0/> led the Yale Medical School as its dean from 1920 to 1935. Dedicated to the new scientific medicine established in Germany, he was equally fervent about "<a1_0><b6_0>social medicine<b6_0/><a1_0/>" and the study of humans in their culture and environment. He established the "<a2_0><b7_0>Yale System<b7_0/><a2_0/>" of teaching, with <a3_0><b8_0>few lectures and fewer exams, and strengthened the full-time faculty system<b8_0/><a3_0/>; he also created the <a4_0><b9_0>graduate-level Yale School of Nursing and the Psychiatry Department<b9_0/><a4_0/>, and built numerous new buildings. Progress toward his plans for an Institute of Human Relations, envisioned as a refuge where social scientists would collaborate with biological scientists in a holistic study of humankind, unfortunately lasted for only a few years before the opposition of resentful anti-Semitic colleagues drove him to resign.
